items.label: prop-lipschitz-diffusion
items.title: Lipschitz Continuity of Adaptive Diffusion
items.content:
414: :label: prop-lipschitz-diffusion
415: 
416: The adaptive diffusion tensor is Lipschitz continuous:
417: 
418: $$
419: \|\Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_1, S_1) - \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_2, S_2)\|_F \le L_\Sigma \cdot d_{\text{state}}((x_1, S_1), (x_2, S_2))
420: $$
421: 
422: where $\|\cdot\|_F$ is the Frobenius norm, $d_{\text{state}}$ is an appropriate state-space metric, and $L_\Sigma$ depends on:
423: - The Lipschitz constant of the fitness Hessian $\nabla^2 V_{\text{fit}}$

items.label: prop-rate-metric-ellipticity
items.title: Convergence Rate Depends on Metric Ellipticity
items.content:
2632: :label: prop-rate-metric-ellipticity
2633: 
2634: The convergence rate $\kappa_{\text{total}}$ depends on the **ellipticity constants** of the emergent metric:
2635: 
2636: $$
2637: \kappa_{\text{total}} = O(\min\{\gamma \tau, \kappa_x, c_{\min}\})
2638: $$
2639: 
2640: where $c_{\min} = \epsilon_\Sigma / (H_{\max} + \epsilon_\Sigma)$ is the lower bound on the eigenvalues of $D_{\text{reg}} = g_{\text{emergent}}^{-1}$.
2641: 
2642: **Interpretation**:
2643: - **Well-conditioned manifold** ($H_{\max} \approx \epsilon_\Sigma$): $c_{\min} \approx \epsilon_\Sigma / 2$ → fast convergence
2644: - **Ill-conditioned manifold** ($H_{\max} \gg \epsilon_\Sigma$): $c_{\min} \approx \epsilon_\Sigma / H_{\max}$ → slower convergence (but still positive!)

items.label: prop-geodesics-fitness
items.title: Geodesics Favor High-Fitness Regions
items.content:
3276: :label: prop-geodesics-fitness
3277: 
3278: The geodesics of the emergent metric $g(x, S)$ are **biased toward high-fitness regions**. Specifically:
3279: 
3280: 1. **Shorter distances in high-fitness regions:** For two points $x_1, x_2 \in \mathcal{X}$, the Riemannian distance:
3281: 
3282: $$
3283: d_g(x_1, x_2) = \inf_{\gamma: x_1 \to x_2} \int_0^1 \sqrt{g_{ab}(\gamma(t), S) \dot{\gamma}^a(t) \dot{\gamma}^b(t)} \, dt
3284: $$
3285: 
3286: is **smaller** when the path passes through regions of high $V_{\text{fit}}$ (low curvature, low metric eigenvalues).
3287: 
3288: 2. **Geodesics avoid high-curvature regions:** The metric eigenvalues are largest where the Hessian $H$ has large positive eigenvalues, which occurs where the fitness landscape is **most convexly curved**. Geodesics bend away from these regions of high metric density to minimize path length.
3289: 
3290: 3. **Connection to natural gradient:** The inverse metric $g^{-1} = D_{\text{reg}}$ defines the **natural gradient**:
3291: 
3292: $$
3293: \nabla^{\text{nat}} V_{\text{fit}} = g^{-1} \nabla V_{\text{fit}}
3294: $$
